title: The Hidden Meanings Behind Popular Food & Drink Emojis

steps.title: Some fruit emojis have hidden meanings.
steps.content: Some fruit emojis have hidden meanings. Oftentimes, fruit emojis have straightforward meanings. However, some fruits, like melons, bananas, and pineapples, can have a multitude of meanings. Here are some of the clear and hidden messages behind your favorite fruit emojis: ğŸ‡ (grapes) emoji: often used in conversations talking about wine or charcuterie boards ğŸˆ (melon) emoji: can sometimes be used to talk about someoneâ€™s curves; 2 melons can represent breasts or testicles ğŸ‰ (watermelon) emoji: recently used as a political symbol to support Palestine, since the fruit colors matches the national colors of the Palestinian flagâ€”red, green, black, and white [1] X Research source ğŸŠ (tangerine) emoji: used to represent an orange; people also use it to talk about cocktails, summer, Florida, and other orange-related things ğŸ‹ (lemon) emoji: represents the actual citrus fruit, but can also be used to talk about vacation, Europe, and BeyoncÃ©â€™s â€œLemonadeâ€ album [2] X Research source ğŸ‹â€ğŸŸ© (lime) emoji: in the Caribbean, the lime emoji symbolizes hanging out, socializing, or getting together ğŸŒ (banana) emoji: besides representing the actual fruit, this emoji may represent male genitalia or be used to say something is â€œbananasâ€ (aka crazy or wild) [3] X Research source ğŸ (pineapple) emoji: mostly represents the literal fruit but can also be used to indicate an open or complicated relationship status ğŸ¥­ (mango) emoji: a representation of the fruit itself but also used to talk about summer, cocktails, and nice weather ğŸ (red apple) emoji: can symbolize the literal fruit, fall, the back to school season, New York City, or the Apple company ğŸ (green apple) emoji: can be used to talk about all things applesâ€”eating apples, picking apples, or more recently, used in a caption if youâ€™re doing Charli XCXâ€™s â€œAppleâ€ dance challenge ğŸ (pear) emoji: usually represents the fruit but may indicate that youâ€™re single and interested in meeting someone ğŸ‘ (peach) emoji: often used to refer to someoneâ€™s butt in texting and on social media ğŸ’ (cherries) emoji: usually represents the literal fruit but can also be used to represent breasts or testicles ğŸ“ (strawberry) emoji: often used in scenarios that are sweet, cute, and girly ğŸ« (blueberries) emoji: usually a representation of the fruit itself, or summertime and relaxation ğŸ¥ (kiwi fruit) emoji: used to talk about healthy food, nice drinks, summer vibes, and to reference Kiwis (New Zealand natives) ğŸ¥¥ (coconut) emoji: can be used to refer to islands and vacations, or used to show toughness or being â€œhard to crackâ€ ğŸ… (tomato) emoji: can be used to express a playful dislike or something, sort of like giving someone a thumbs down ğŸ«’ (olive) emoji: a popular emoji when talking about food, martinis, and Greece; can also be used as a symbol of peace like extending an olive branch

steps.title: Some vegetable emojis arenâ€™t exactly what they seem.
steps.content: Some vegetable emojis arenâ€™t exactly what they seem. Like fruits, vegetables can also have alternative meanings, depending on the context of the conversation. If youâ€™re ever confused when someone sends you a veggie emoji, hereâ€™s what they might be saying: ğŸ¥‘ (avocado) emoji: a symbol of health and wellness, relating to eating healthy foods and building healthy habits ğŸ† (eggplant) emoji: used to talk about healthy dishes and vegetables; can also be used to refer to male genitalia [4] X Research source ğŸ¥” (potato) emoji: usually refers to meals that feature potatoes, but can also be used to insult someoneâ€™s behavior or appearance (â€œcouch potatoâ€) ğŸ¥• (carrot) emoji: often symbolizes gardening and healthy eating; may be used to represent male genitalia; anti-vax groups have also used the emoji as a code for the word â€œvaccineâ€ to avoid censorship [5] X Research source ğŸŒ½ (ear of corn) emoji: a slang term for porn; users drop the corn emoji when they want to discuss adult content on social media (to avoid being flagged or banned on the platform) [6] X Research source ğŸŒ¶ï¸ (hot pepper) emoji: used when something is hot or spicy; often commented on posts when people look good ğŸ«‘ (bell pepper) emoji: can be used to talk about bell peppers, dishes that contain bell peppers, or food in general ğŸ¥’ (cucumber) emoji: mostly used when talking about dishes that feature cucumbers ğŸ¥¬ (leafy green) emoji: can represent lettuce, kale, arugula, spinach, and other leafy greens ğŸ¥¦ (broccoli) emoji: represents health and eating healthy, but may also represent marijuana [7] X Research source ğŸ§„ (garlic) emoji: used to discuss common cooking ingredients, bad breath, or ways to fend off vampires ğŸ§… (onion) emoji: primarily refers to cooking, but can also be used to discuss sadness, tears, or Shrek ğŸ¥œ (peanuts) emoji: can be used to talk about edible nuts or metaphorical nutsâ€”slang for â€œcrazy,â€ â€œtesticles,â€ or â€œto nutâ€ (ejaculate) ğŸ«˜ (beans) emoji: may be used to talk about food, flatulence, or coffee beans; people also use it to discuss money, counting, or a small amount of something; can also refer to the head or brain ğŸŒ° (chestnut) emoji: used in social media posts about autumn, winter, squirrels, and the holiday season; can also represent testicles or a womanâ€™s butt ğŸ«š (ginger) emoji: can symbolize spice, flavor, cooking, or baking; may also be used to refer to redheads ğŸ«› (pea pod) emoji: can be used to discuss actual pea pods, peas, or vegetables in general; may be used along with the phrase â€œtwo peas in a podâ€ to show affection toward someone ğŸ„â€ğŸŸ« (brown mushroom) emoji: outside its literal interpretation, this emoji can represent food prep, foraging, decay, or long walks in nature

steps.title: Some prepared food emojis also have double meanings.
steps.content: Some prepared food emojis also have double meanings. Meat, cheese, and bread might seem like staple ingredients in your kitchen, but they also have specific meanings beyond their literal representations. Here are some of the secret meanings behind your favorite prepared food emojis: ğŸ (bread) emoji: represents sustenance, nourishment, the basic needs of life, and getting money (â€œletâ€™s get this breadâ€) ğŸ¥ (croissant) emoji: often used to refer to breakfast, France, and baking in general ğŸ¥– (baguette bread) emoji: commonly used to talk about France ğŸ«“ (flatbread) emoji: symbolizes any type of flatbread, soft or crunchy; can also be used to talk about corn-based flatbreads like arepas, gorditas, or pupusas ğŸ¥¨ (pretzel) emoji: associated with baseball, Germany, and baked goods; sometimes, the emoji can be a metaphor for something â€œtwistedâ€ ğŸ¥¯ (bagel) emoji: used to talk about breakfast, bread, and areas where bagels are popular (like Montreal and New York City) ğŸ¥ (pancakes) emoji: often used to talk about breakfast or brunch; also associated with the Christian observance of Shrove Tuesday ğŸ§‡ (waffle) emoji: most often used to talk about breakfast or other sweet treats; can also be used when someone is â€œwafflingâ€ (aka not getting to the point) ğŸ§€ (cheese wedge) emoji: represents all types of cheese; also used when something or someone is being â€œcheesyâ€ ğŸ– (meat on bone) emoji: used in reference to barbeques, cooking meat, and meat in general; also associated with early, cave-dwelling people and ancient foods and practices ğŸ— (poultry leg) emoji: most often used to talk about chicken wings since there is currently no wing emoji ğŸ¥© (cut of meat) emoji: symbolizes cookouts, barbeques, steak, and meat in general ğŸ¥“ (bacon) emoji: use this emoji when you want to tell someone youâ€™re cooking breakfast for them or want to go to a diner together ğŸ” (hamburger) emoji: used to talk about eating hamburgers, especially on National Hamburger Day (May 28) ğŸŸ (french fries) emoji: commonly used to represent french fries, fast food, or McDonaldâ€™s ğŸ• (pizza) emoji: most often represents pizza or food in general when someone is hungry; in rare cases, it may be used to suggest a threesome ğŸŒ­ (hot dog) emoji: accompanies messages about food, baseball, small dogs, barbeques, summer, and New York City; may also refer to male genitalia ğŸ¥ª (sandwich) emoji: represents one of the most loved food items; often used to talk about meals or lunch ğŸŒ® (taco) emoji: can represent a love of Mexican food and culture; may also represent female genitalia or oral sex [8] X Research source ğŸŒ¯ (burrito) emoji: used to express a desire for Mexican or Southwestern food ğŸ«” (tamale) emoji: represents the traditional Mexican dish made of masa or dough, filled with meat, cheese, and veggies and then steamed in a leaf wrapper ğŸ¥™ (stuffed flatbread) emoji: represents a pita sandwich; used to talk about quick, easy, and healthy lunch options and recipes ğŸ§† (falafel) emoji: used when talking about Middle Eastern dishes and culture, and vegetarian options in general ğŸ¥š (egg) emoji: refers to eggs when used in cooking and in reference to breakfast foods, such as scrambled eggs; also used to commemorate Easter ğŸ³ (cooking) emoji: most commonly used when talking about breakfast or cooking in general ğŸ¥˜ (shallow pan of food) emoji: symbolizes all the different types of food and meals that can be cooked in a pan ğŸ² (pot of food) emoji: used to talk about any kind of food that can be cooked in a pot ğŸ«• (fondue) emoji: represents the cheese or chocolate-based snack used to dip bread, fruit, or vegetables ğŸ¥£ (bowl with spoon) emoji: indicates that youâ€™re enjoying a bowl or soup or a bowl of cereal ğŸ¥— (green salad) emoji: represents health, wellness, and vegetarian or vegan options ğŸ¿ (popcorn) emoji: used to talk about movies, fairs, or carnivals; can also be used when drama is unfolding ğŸ§ˆ (butter) emoji: used to talk about baking, cooking, or any food that has lots of butter in it ğŸ§‚ (salt) emoji: can indicate that something is too salty or needs more flavor; metaphorically, it can mean someone is being salty (aka bitter or upset) ğŸ¥« (canned food) emoji: symbolizes all types of canned food and the canning process; often used to talk about tomato sauce or tomato soup ğŸ (spaghetti) emoji: used to talk about pasta, Italy, or Italian food

steps.title: Most Asian food emojis have straightforward meanings.
steps.content: Most Asian food emojis have straightforward meanings. Almost all of the following emojis represent food. But, if youâ€™re confused over what some of the dishes are supposed to be, weâ€™ve provided a quick description of what each emoji represents and where it comes from: ğŸ± (bento box) emoji: represents a traditional Japanese boxed lunch or Asian cuisine in general ğŸ˜ (rice cracker) emoji: symbolizes a Japanese senbei wrapped in a sheet of nori or seaweed ğŸ™ (rice ball) emoji: represents an onigiri, or round or triangular balls of rice wrapped in nori and filled with fish, cooked meat, or pickled plum ğŸš (cooked rice) emoji: used to discuss specific dishes you eat with rice or Asian food in general ğŸ› (curry rice) emoji: represents a popular dish in Japan and India ğŸœ (steaming bowl) emoji: often used to talk about ramen and other steamy dishes ğŸ  (roasted sweet potato) emoji: represents an offering to the full moon in Japan during the Moon Viewing harvest festival ğŸ¢ (oden) emoji: represents the traditional Japanese dish of fish cakes, eggs, and radishes served on a skewer ğŸ£ (sushi) emoji: symbolizes nigirizushi, a type of sushi made with bite-sized balls of sushi rice topped with raw fish ğŸ¤ (fried shrimp) emoji: represents tempura shrimp or all cooked seafood; some people use it to convey â€œsaltyâ€ feelings of anger, bitterness, or contempt ğŸ¥ (fish cake with swirl) emoji: represents narutomaki, a type of kamaboko made from surimi, salt, sugar, egg whites, fish sauce, and sake ğŸ¥® (moon cake) emoji: used to mark the Mid-Autumn festival which is celebrated in China, Vietnam, and communities in East and Southeast Asia ğŸ¡ (dango) emoji: represents the sweet Japanese dumpling made from rice flour and served on a skewer ğŸ¥Ÿ (dumpling) emoji: associated with cuisines all over the worldâ€”China (jiaozi), Japan (gyoza or dango), Poland (pierogi), and Spain and Latin America (empanada) ğŸ¥  (fortune cookie) emoji: used to wish someone good luck or to hope that something good happens ğŸ¥¡ (takeout box) emoji: commonly used to represent Chinese takeout and other food you want to eat to-go

steps.title: Some seafood emojis can represent multiple things.
steps.content: Some seafood emojis can represent multiple things. Generally, seafood emojis are fairly straightforward in meaning, but some represent slang phrases and expressions. If someone sends you a crab or shrimp emoji when the topic isnâ€™t about food, they might mean: ğŸ¦€ (crab) emoji: used to represent crab as food or being â€œcrabby;â€ can also represent Cancer in the Western zodiac ğŸ¦ (lobster) emoji: can represent shellfish and gourmet dining experiences; also a symbol of the transgender community since it has both male and female characteristics ğŸ¦ (shrimp) emoji: represents crustaceans and seafood; Gen Z can use it to say someone is short or theyâ€™re feeling small ğŸ¦‘ (squid) emoji: primarily used to talk about the ocean and marine life; may be used to talk about the show Squid Game ğŸ™ (octopus) emoji: can refer to calamari or sea life in general; people also use it as slang for hugs or cuddles ğŸ¦ª (oyster) emoji: a symbol of indulgence and the finer things in life; perfect for sharing an oyster bar experience [9] X Research source

steps.title: Some of the sweetest emojis have alternative meanings.
steps.content: Some of the sweetest emojis have alternative meanings. Some young people use dessert emojis to represent dirty things, such as sex or illicit drugs. If someone sends you a sweet emoji and youâ€™re totally lost, here are some possible meanings: ğŸ¦ (soft ice cream) emoji: used to talk about summer and enjoying ice cream on the go ğŸ§ (shaved ice) emoji: associated with Hawaiian shave ice or Japanese kakigori; used to represent a wide variety of frozen desserts, warm weather, and tropical locations ğŸ¨ (ice cream) emoji: used to represent ice cream or dessert; often used on National Ice Cream Day (July 18) ğŸ© (doughnut) emoji: symbolizes sweetness, indulgence, and desserts in general; can be used to talk about The Simpsons or negative opinions of police officers ğŸª (cookie) emoji: represents all kinds of cookies; may be code for a large batch of drugs [10] X Research source ğŸ‚ (birthday cake) emoji: used to celebrate birthdays and other special occasions ğŸ° (shortcake) emoji: used to celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, achievements, or any occasion where youâ€™d have a cake ğŸ§ (cupcake) emoji: most often used to talk about baking, birthdays, or something sweet ğŸ¥§ (pie) emoji: used to reference pies, desserts, or Pi Day (March 14) ğŸ« (chocolate bar) emoji: primarily represents chocolate or a love of candy, sweets, and sugary snacks; can also be used to tell someone how sweet they are; may represent xanax in street slang [11] X Research source ğŸ¬ (candy) emoji: typically refers to actual candy; can also be used to describe someone or something as sweet metaphorically ğŸ­ (lollipop) emoji: often refers to the literal candy, but may also imply an interest in oral sex ğŸ® (custard) emoji: used to represent any custard-like dessert like flan or crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e ğŸ¯ (honey pot) emoji: usually represents sweetness, a term of endearment, or a pot of honey, but can also refer to oxycodone

steps.title: Some drink emojis represent other slang words and phrases.
steps.content: Some drink emojis represent other slang words and phrases. Most drink emojis symbolize alcohol and celebration, but some can be code for street slang. Hereâ€™s the lowdown on what all the drink and beverage emojis mean: ğŸ¼ (baby bottle) emoji: typically used to talk about babies, baby showers, and pregnancies; may be code for cough syrup in street slang [12] X Research source ğŸ¥› (glass of milk) emoji: most often refers to literal milk, but can be slang for a â€œhot white chick thatâ€™s badâ€ â˜• (hot beverage) emoji: commonly used to represent coffee, tea, mornings, or breakfast ğŸ«– (teapot) emoji: can be used to discuss tea, tea time, or warm beverages in general; may also be used to refer to gossip (â€œspill the teaâ€) ğŸµ (teacup without handle) emoji: often interpreted as a bowl of pea soup or a cup of matcha; may be used to refer to someoneâ€™s physical attractiveness (â€œher body is teaâ€) ğŸ¶ (sake) emoji: often used for joyous or celebratory occasions that call for sake or a nice sushi or omakase experience ğŸ¾ (bottle with popping cork) emoji: can be used to celebrate birthdays, weddings, New Yearâ€™s Eve, or other monumental occasions ğŸ· (wine glass) emoji: often used to represent wine, romance, fine dining, wealth, and alcoholic drinks ğŸ¸ (cocktail glass) emoji: represents one of the most popular cocktailsâ€”a martini; used when talking about specific drinks or a night out ğŸ¹ (tropical drink) emoji: often used to talk about vacations, relaxing, and fruity drinks ğŸº (beer mug) emoji: represents beer, bars, partying, and drunkenness in general ğŸ» (clinking beer mugs) emoji: commonly used to discuss drunk moments with friends ğŸ¥‚ (clinking glasses) emoji: used to say â€œcheersâ€ or â€œHappy New Year;â€ perfect when congratulating someone or celebrating something great ğŸ¥ƒ (tumbler glass) emoji: represents dark-colored alcohols, such as whiskey, bourbon, or scotch ğŸ«— (pouring liquid) emoji: can be used to honor the dead by pouring out a drink in someone's memory; can also be used to ask someone to â€œspill the teaâ€ or tell them the gossip ğŸ¥¤ (cup with straw) emoji: typically used to talk about someoneâ€™s thirst, a fast food place, or a house party ğŸ§‹ (bubble tea) emoji: symbolizes the popular Taiwanese drink made with milk, sweetened tea, and tapioca balls ğŸ§ƒ (beverage box) emoji: represents any boxes of juice that are consumed with a straw ğŸ§‰ (mate) emoji: represents the traditional South American caffeinated drink made by steeping yerba Mate leaves in hot water

steps.title: Most dishware emojis are fairly straightforward in meaning.
steps.content: Most dishware emojis are fairly straightforward in meaning. Generally, people use dishware emojis to talk about eating or setting the table. However, some can have hidden meanings that move beyond the surface. Here are the meanings behind the most popular dishware emojis: ğŸ¥¢ (chopsticks) emoji: often used when talking about Asian dishes, such as noodles ğŸ½ï¸ (fork and knife with plate) emoji: used when talking about having a meal or sitting down to eat ğŸ´ (fork and knife) emoji: used when discussing eating or setting the table; this emoji spikes in popularity on Thanksgiving ğŸ¥„ (spoon) emoji: used when talking about cooking and eating; may also describe being the â€œbigâ€ or â€œlittle spoonâ€ ğŸ”ª (kitchen knife) emoji: often used to refer to cooking, food, or kitchen-related activities; may be used to indicate cutting or stabbing someone ğŸ«™ (jar) emoji: can refer to any food that comes from a jar, such as pickles or preserves

steps.title: Create different emoji combinations to play â€œGuess the Food by Emoji.â€
steps.content: Create different emoji combinations to play â€œGuess the Food by Emoji.â€ If you want to test your food knowledge and have fun with your friends, mix a few emojis togethers to come up with a unique message. Not sure what to send? Here are a few examples to help you get started: ğŸğŸ¥§ = shepherd's pie ğŸŒ²ğŸ = pineapple ğŸŒŸğŸ’µ = Starbucks â™¨ï¸ğŸ¶ = hot dog ğŸŠğŸ’ğŸ“ğŸ‘Š = fruit punch ğŸ’¥ğŸŒ½ = popcorn ğŸŒğŸ’” = banana split â˜ï¸ğŸ¬ = cotton candy ğŸ§…ğŸ’ = onion ring ğŸšğŸ‚ = rice cake â³ğŸ§™â€â™€ï¸ = sandwich ğŸ§€ğŸ‚ = cheesecake ğŸŒ½â„ï¸ = cornflakes ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡·ğŸ = french toast ğŸƒğŸª½ = buffalo wings ğŸŒğŸ = banana bread ğŸŒ½ğŸ¶ = corn dog ğŸ¬ğŸŒ½ = candy corn ğŸ”®ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ³ğŸ”‘ = fortune cookie ğŸŒ®ğŸ”” = Taco Bell ğŸ¥›ğŸ¤ = milkshake ğŸ’¦ğŸˆ = watermelon ğŸ”ğŸ¤´ = Burger King ğŸ¥©âš½ = meatball
